Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grant Support for Association for Computing Machinery (AC) WiSec 2018

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal supports six students for their travel to attend the 11th Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Conference on Security and Privacy in Wireless and Mobile Networks (WiSec 2018) to be held at the KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Sweden, from June 18 to June 20, 2018. WiSec is one of the leading international conferences on the security and privacy of wireless communications and mobile networks, attracting students, researchers and industry specialists from all over the world. Participation in conferences such as WiSec is an extremely important part of graduate students' research and career development, providing the opportunity for them to present their own work, attend panel and keynote speech sessions, interact with peers and senior researchers, and exposure to leading edge work in the fields of wireless networks security and mobile privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WiSec is one of the leading international conferences on privacy and security of wireless networks, wireless communication and mobile devices. It is one of the main forums where researchers and practitioners are free to share and discuss a wide variety of scientific ideas for improving security, privacy and anonymity of mobile devices and wireless networks. With increased recognition of the importance of security in mobile networks and devices, interest in WiSec has surged in recent years. Thanks to the generous support of the National Science Foundation, six students from US-based institutions were able to attend the 2018 WiSec conference in Stockholm, Sweden. Applicants were evaluated by a committee of researchers based on their research contributions and abilities to broaden perspectives and diversity. The students presented their work in papers and posters, and trip reports from the students demonstrated that they benefited personally and professionally from attending the conference because of the ability to discuss their results with leading researchers in the area of mobile and wireless security and privacy. Outreach efforts were made to broaden participation through outreach to professional organizations encouraging minority involvement in computing and engineering, which is a continual goal of conference organizers, and we expect that such efforts will lead to even more success in the future.
